text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 34A30 37B55 37D05 34D09 37D10 37N10 finite-time dynamics; hyperbolicity; spectral theorem; robustness; linearization; stable manifold; nonautonomous differential equations serial article Karrasch, Daniel Number: 6109882 Linearization of hyperbolic finite-time processes. 2013 Summary: We adapt the notion of processes to introduce an abstract framework for dynamics in finite time, i.e. on compact time-sets. For linear finite-time processes a notion of hyperbolicity namely exponential monotonicity dichotomy (EMD) is introduced, thereby generalizing and unifying several existing approaches. We present a spectral theory for linear processes in a coherent way, based only on a logarithmic difference quotient. In this abstract setting we introduce a new topology, prove robustness of EMD and provide exact perturbation bounds. We suggest a new, intrinsic approach for the investigation of linearizations of finite-time processes, including finite-time analogues of the local (un-)stable manifold theorem and theorem of linearized asymptotic stability. As an application, we discuss our results for ordinary differential equations on a compact time-interval.

math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="8k+3" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:mrow xml:id="m1.1.5" xref="m1.1.5.cmml"><m:mrow xml:id="m1.1.5.1" xref="m1.1.5.1.cmml"><m:mn xml:id="m1.1.1" xref="m1.1.1.cmml">8</m:mn><m:mo xml:id="m1.1.5.1.1" xref="m1.1.5.1.1.cmml">‚Å¢</m:mo><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.2" xref="m1.1.2.cmml">k</m:mi></m:mrow><m:mo xml:id="m1.1.3" xref="m1.1.3.cmml">+</m:mo><m:mn xml:id="m1.1.4" xref="m1.1.4.cmml">3</m:mn></m:mrow><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:apply xml:id="m1.1.5.cmml" xref="m1.1.5"><m:plus xml:id="m1.1.3.cmml" xref="m1.1.3"/><m:apply xml:id="m1.1.5.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.5.1"><m:times xml:id="m1.1.5.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.5.1.1"/><m:cn type="integer" xml:id="m1.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.1">8</m:cn><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.2.cmml" xref="m1.1.2">k</m:ci></m:apply><m:cn type="integer" xml:id="m1.1.4.cmml" xref="m1.1.4">3</m:cn></m:apply></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">8k+3</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 11G05 elliptic curve; congruent numbers; non-congruent numbers; rank serial article Reinholz, Lindsey; Spearman, Blair K.; Yang, Qiduan Number: 6110194 Families of non-congruent numbers with arbitrarily many prime factors. 2013 Summary: A method is given for generating families of non-congruent numbers with arbitrarily many prime factors. We then use this method to construct an infinite set of new families of these numbers with prime factors of the form math1 .

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C85 05C20 directed graph; canonical construction path; bipartite; structure generation serial article Brinkmann, Gunnar Number: 6109885 Generating regular directed graphs. 2013 The main result of this article is efficient algorithm generate all regular directed graph with a given number of vertices and given its degree. Directed graphs are constructed from regular bipartite (i.e. undirected) graphs.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C70 05C15 serial article Karab√°≈°, J√°n; M√°ƒçajov√°, Edita; Nedela, Roman Number: 6106899 6-decomposition of snarks. 2013 Summary: A snark is a cubic graph with no proper 3-edge-colouring. In 1996, Nedela and ≈†koviera proved the following theorem: Let math1 be a snark with an math2 -edge-cut, math3 , whose removal leaves two 3-edge-colourable components math4 and math5 . Then both math6 and math7 can be completed to two snarks math8 and math9 of order not exceeding that of math10 by adding at most math11 vertices, where the number math12 only depends on math13 . The known values of the function math14 are math15 (Goldberg, 1981) [6], and math16 (Cameron et al. 1987) [4]. The value math17 is not known and is apparently difficult to calculate. In 1979, Jaeger conjectured that there are no 7-cyclically-connected snarks. If this conjecture holds true, then math18 is the last important value to determine. The paper is aimed attacking the problem of determining math19 by investigating the structure and colour properties of potential complements in 6-decompositions of snarks. We find a set of 14 complements that suffice to perform 6-decompositions of snarks with at most 30 vertices. We show that if this set is not complete to perform 6-decompositions of all snarks, then math20 and there are strong restrictions on the structure of (possibly) missing complements. Part of the proofs are computer assisted.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 82-02 82D30 book Contucci, Pierluigi; Giardin√†, Cristian Number: 6107945 Perspectives on spin glasses. 2013 Preliminary review / Publisher‚Äôs description: Presenting and developing the theory of spin glasses as a prototype for complex systems, this book is a rigorous and up-to-date introduction to their properties. The book combines a mathematical description with a physical insight of spin glass models. Topics covered include the physical origins of those models and their treatment with replica theory; mathematical properties like correlation inequalities and their use in the thermodynamic limit theory; main exact solutions of the mean field models and their probabilistic structures; and the theory of the structural properties of the spin glass phase such as stochastic stability and the overlap identities. Finally, a detailed account is given of the recent numerical simulation results and properties, including overlap equivalence, ultrametricity and decay of correlations. The book is ideal for mathematical physicists and probabilists working in disordered systems.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 11M41 11M32 22E55 11F25 11F70 30B40 double Dirichlet series; Hecke math1 -functions; meromorphic continuation; torus periods of cusp forms serial article Reznikov, Andre Number: 6110195 Torus period coefficients on PGL(2) and Dirichlet series. 2013 Summary: We fix a quadratic number field math2 , and the corresponding torus in PGL(2). We consider twisted (by a Hecke character of the field math3 ) torus periods of automorphic functions. We prove meromorphic continuation for a Dirichlet series generated by these twisted periods.

math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="M(d\geq 2)" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:mrow xml:id="m1.1b" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.1">M</m:mi><m:mrow xml:id="m1.1.7" xref="m1.1.7.cmml"><m:mo xml:id="m1.1.2" xref="m1.1.2.cmml">(</m:mo><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.3">d</m:mi><m:mo xml:id="m1.1.4" xref="m1.1.4.cmml">‚â•</m:mo><m:mn xml:id="m1.1.5" xref="m1.1.5.cmml">2</m:mn><m:mo xml:id="m1.1.6" xref="m1.1.6.cmml">)</m:mo></m:mrow></m:mrow><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:cerror xml:id="m1.1a.cmml" xref="m1.1"><m:csymbol cd="ambiguous" xml:id="m1.1b.cmml" xref="m1.1">fragments</m:csymbol><m:csymbol cd="unknown" xml:id="m1.1c.cmml" xref="m1.1">M</m:csymbol><m:cerror xml:id="m1.1.7.cmml" xref="m1.1.7"><m:csymbol cd="ambiguous" xml:id="m1.1.7a.cmml" xref="m1.1.7">fragments</m:csymbol><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.2.cmml" xref="m1.1.2">normal-(</m:ci><m:csymbol cd="unknown" xml:id="m1.1.7b.cmml" xref="m1.1.7">d</m:csymbol><m:geq xml:id="m1.1.4.cmml" xref="m1.1.4"/><m:cn type="integer" xml:id="m1.1.5.cmml" xref="m1.1.5">2</m:cn><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.6.cmml" xref="m1.1.6">normal-)</m:ci></m:cerror></m:cerror></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1c" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">M(d\geq 2)</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 37C20 37D30 37J25 53D05 70H14 Hamiltonian flow; hyperbolic orbit; dominated splitting serial article Bessa, M√°rio; Rocha, Jorge; Torres, Maria Joana Number: 6109884 Hyperbolicity and stability for Hamiltonian flows. 2013 Summary: We prove that a Hamiltonian star system, defined on a 2d-dimensional symplectic manifold math1 , is Anosov. As a consequence we obtain the proof of the stability conjecture for Hamiltonians. This generalizes the 4-dimensional results in Bessa et al. (2010) [5].

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 11M26 11M06 11F27 42A38 classical Riemann‚Äôs zeta function; dilogarithm function; Mellin transform; meromorphic character of math1 ; zero-free regions of the zeta function; bounds on the zeta function; integral representations of the zeta function; series of zeta functions; series of gamma functions; generalized symmetrized M√ºntz formula serial article Albeverio, Sergio; Cacciapuoti, Claudio Number: 6110192 The Riemann zeta in terms of the dilogarithm. 2013 Summary: We give a representation of the classical Riemann math2 -function in the half plane math3 in terms of a Mellin transform involving the real part of the dilogarithm function with an argument on the unit circle (associated Clausen math4 -function). We also derive corresponding representations involving the derivatives of the math5 -function. A generalized symmetrized M√ºntz-type formula is also derived. For a special choice of test functions it connects to our integral representation of the math6 -function, providing also a computation of a concrete Mellin transform. Certain formulae involving series of zeta functions and gamma functions are also derived.

math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="C^{{1,\alpha}}" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:msup xml:id="m1.1.3" xref="m1.1.3.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.1" xref="m1.1.1.cmml">C</m:mi><m:mrow xml:id="m1.1.2.1" xref="m1.1.2.1.cmml"><m:mn xml:id="m1.1.2.1.1" xref="m1.1.2.1.1.cmml">1</m:mn><m:mo xml:id="m1.1.2.1a" xref="m1.1.2.1.cmml">,</m:mo><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.2.1.3" xref="m1.1.2.1.3.cmml">Œ±</m:mi></m:mrow></m:msup><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:apply xml:id="m1.1.3.cmml" xref="m1.1.3"><m:csymbol cd="ambiguous" xml:id="m1.1.3.1.cmml">superscript</m:csymbol><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.1">C</m:ci><m:apply xml:id="m1.1.2.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.2.1"><m:list xml:id="m1.1.2.1.4.cmml"/><m:cn type="integer" xml:id="m1.1.2.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.2.1.1">1</m:cn><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.2.1.3.cmml" xref="m1.1.2.1.3">Œ±</m:ci></m:apply></m:apply></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">C^{{1,\alpha}}</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 34-XX 35-XX serial article Lian, Zeng; Young, Lai-Sang; Zeng, Chongchun Number: 6109883 Absolute continuity of stable foliations for systems on Banach spaces. 2013 Summary: We prove the absolute continuity of stable foliations for math1 maps of Banach spaces satisfying a globally defined infinitesimal invariant cones condition. Proofs of regularity for center and stable manifolds needed for the main theorem are included. Our results are applicable to dynamical systems generated by ordinary, partial, or functional differential equations, including non-autonomous differential equations that are periodic in time.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35Q30 35D30 76D05 compressible Navier-Stokes equations; time-varying domain; slip boundary conditions serial article Feireisl, Eduard; Kreml, Ond≈ôej; Neƒçasov√°, ≈†√°rka; Neustupa, Ji≈ô√≠; Stebel, Jan Number: 6109877 Weak solutions to the barotropic Navier-Stokes system with slip boundary conditions in time dependent domains. 2013 Summary: We consider the compressible (barotropic) Navier-Stokes system on time dependent domains, supplemented with slip boundary conditions. Our approach is based on penalization of the boundary behavior, viscosity, and the pressure in the weak formulation. Global-in-time weak solutions are obtained.
